Award.AwardTitle: NSF INCLUDES: A Program Designed to Recruit, Retain, and Train Hispanic Women in STEM Disciplines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

This project seeks to prepare female Hispanic students for leadership in the STEM workforce. The project seeks to determine if a blended set of STEM engagement activities including summer intensive laboratory-based experiential learning and out-of-school STEM activities, peer support, mentoring, and financial assistance can help to take target students through a traditional leaky workforce and educational pipeline resulting in matriculation to and graduation from undergraduate STEM programs. If successful, the work will increase participation and leadership of Hispanic women in the STEM workforce. To accomplish these goals, the PIs will: (1) work with partners to identify, recruit, and screen bright, energetic Hispanic females in their freshman year of high school who show promise and interest in STEM disciplines; (2) engage selected students and their families in formal and informal STEM learning both throughout the school year and during summer residential experiences to enable the students to further develop and clarify their STEM calling; (3)prepare the students to matriculate to undergraduate college; (4) provide program participants with full-tuition scholarships to ensure undergraduate education is attainable; and (5) at our institution and partner colleges, provide dedicated advisors and mentors and cohort activities to ensure undergraduate persistence and success.


Technical Summary

The PIs seek to prepare female Hispanic students for leadership in the STEM workforce. To compete in the global economy, maintain national security, and meet serious environmental challenges, more skilled graduates are needed to fill STEM jobs. An untapped source of talent exists in those populations that continue to be underrepresented in STEM fields, including women and people of color. This work will help to determine if a blended set of STEM engagement activities including summer intensive laboratory-based experiential learning and out-of-school STEM activities, peer support, mentoring, and financial assistance can help to take target students through a traditional leaky pipeline resulting in matriculation to and graduation from undergraduate STEM education. The work builds on research that shows that mentored research opportunities and peer support and interaction improves persistence in female students. It also builds on regional models of collective impact whereby a variety of corporate, nonprofit, and foundation organizations successfully join together for large-impact projects. If successful, the work will increase participation and leadership of Hispanic women in the STEM workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pathways to Science/Caminos a la Ciencia endeavored to advance the efforts of the INCLUDES program to understand and promote practices that motivate underrepresented minorities to pursue educational pathways to STEM occupations.  This pilot project worked toward identifying and addressing the factors which influence Latinas to lose interest in pursuing STEM education throughout their high school years.  These factors can include lack of appropriate STEM-focused opportunities during high school, language barriers which prohibit their participation in these activities, lack of family or community encouragement to pursue STEM education, and financial pressures. The project team assembled to accomplish this goal consisted of Randolph-Macon College, which served as the backbone organization, working together with a group of STEM-focused Fortune 500 corporations and nonprofits, as well as state and local government and local school systems. The work built upon institutional strengths - a long-standing history of leadership in education of women in STEM fields, strong relationships with partner organizations, and a leadership team with expertise in both STEM education and the specific needs of the Latino community.                                                                                                              

The program identified promising students during their freshman year of high school. Students who were selected to join the program were invited to campus for each of two consecutive summers (after the freshman and sophomore years), where they participated in targeted activities designed to accomplish several goals - to create a cohesive cohort with an identity embracing intellectual interdisciplinary STEM enquiry, to develop and nurture leadership skills, to expose the cohort to prominent successful Latinas in STEM fields, and to develop skills which lead to success in applying to and persisting in a college environment. Synergistic activities were included for these students and their families to extend the mission into the academic year. At the conclusion of each summer of the program, students earned modest scholarships to an accredited institution of their choice. The long-term goal of the project is to follow these initial cohorts of students through high school and their matriculation to college.  Initial data obtained during the INCLUDES funding period were promising, as every member of each cohort was retained in the program throughout the duration of the project and every member indicated an intention to pursue a career in a STEM field and to attend college.  

The program added to the broader base of knowledge on recruiting, training, and providing induction support to Latinas by exploring the following research question: How does engagement, including attitudes, measurements of interest in STEM, and interest in pursuing college education in STEM change for the target population, compared to initial attitudes, over the period of observation for this project?  Through multiple data collection pathways, including the Student Attitudes Toward STEM (S-STEM) Survey, which measures changes in confidence and efficacy in STEM subjects, 21stcentury learning skills and interest in STEM careers, pre- and post-camp surveys, used to measure interest in STEM topics covered in the camp, in specific STEM disciplines, and family engagement, and observational assessments of engagements with family members throughout the program, the project contributed to the broader base of knowledge for best practices in recruitment and retention of Latinas in STEM fields.
